ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Introductory understanding of how to speak, read, write in, and listen to Chinese.
I learned to read, write, listen to, and speak mandarin chinese at a surprisingly high level.
This course was a great introductory language course. It taught me how to study grammar, characters, and vocabulary by starting small and gradually pickup up the pace.
I learned better study habits as I needed to review and study each of the characters every day.
Learning basic structures for Chinese language.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very well organized, but it is a lot of work.

Strengths- engaging, collaborative, fun classroom environment. Engaging and passionate professor. 
Weaknesses- can't think of any. This is really a wonderful course and professor.

This course is well designed to force you to study chinese (which is what youre ideally taking it to do). The main weakness Ill note is that I still find it difficult to hear and speak tones, which is likely more due to the difficulty of the language than the structure of the course.
I enjoyed the range of projects to evaluate our learning like oral exams, written tests, and speaking presentations.
I think that a major strength is the smaller size of the class. I felt that I was able to connect with the classmates and also received a lot of attention from the instructor.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you're interested in learning the language.
Yes, I absolutely would. I was shocked at how much I could learn in one semester.

I wasnt originally planning to take this class, but i switched into it from spanish at the last minute. Im so happy I did. 

If youre considering taking this, know: this course is A LOT of work. If youre actually doing everything assigned, its around an hour of class per day, plus an hour of homework, plus an hour of studying (for around 3 hours of work a day).

BUT, its worth it. Mandarin is super useful and extremely interesting to learn. The small class sizes lead to you feeling more engaged and friendly with your classmates, and sort of a type-2 fun bond. The professors are amazing, and there is a lot of support.

A new language might be the most valuable thing you can learn at yale, and mandarin is one of the best choices you can make.
Yes. The size of the class helps facilitate individual learning and helps foster important relationship between students and teacher.
I would recommend this course if you are willing to put in many hours of studying each day to keep up
